original_conversation.content:
[frustrated] Twenty-three years. Twenty-three years I've been running this clinic and now they're just... pulling the plug. You know what the worst part is? We're actually winning right now. Like, Marcus—he just got his two-year chip last week. [pause] Two years clean. He's got a job, he's seeing his kids again, he's... he's doing everything right. And Sarah, she's, um... she's finally stable after bouncing between programs for what, five years? [bitter] But sure, let's cut funding now. 

I mean, do they even understand what happens when you just—when you yank people off methadone? [speaking fast] It's not like stopping antibiotics, you can't just... people will die. Actually die. And I'm supposed to, what, tell forty-seven patients that sorry, we're done here, good luck finding another clinic that takes Medicaid an hour away? [sigh] 

Maria came in yesterday, she was so proud, showing me pictures of her granddaughter. First time she's been allowed to babysit. [very sad] She asked me if we'd still be here for her six-month review. I couldn't even... I just smiled and said we'd see. 

[quietly] All these spreadsheets and budget meetings, they don't see faces. They see numbers. But these are people who are finally, finally getting their lives back, and we're just... we're abandoning them.

subject: Your methadone clinic closing due to budget cuts just as you're seeing your most successful patient outcomes
